field_reports.description: Liberia has confirmed five (5) cases in three counties. According to the National Public Health Institute of Liberia (NPHIL), the cases have been traced and reported since January this year. The pronouncement was made on Friday, 16th of August. Liberia has recently conducted a monkeypox baseline preparedness assessment using the WHO AFRO. Results from this assessment show that the country's overall preparedness capacity for monkeypox is currently at 51%, which indicates a need for improvement. There is a draft preparedness and response plan has been developed. According to the plan, 13 thematic pillars have been identified as requiring strengthening and prioritization. To enhance the country's preparedness capacity to the target level of 85% or higher, resources are needed to address the key gaps in 13 thematic areas.

results.name: LBR: Epidemic - 08-2024 - Liberia Mpox Outbreak

field_reports.description: Torrential rainfall in Monrovia and its environs has caused flash, coastal and river basin flooding affecting over 35 communities in the last 72 hours. According to a joint assessment conducted by the NDMA local community structures and the Liberian Red Cross Community-Based Action Teams (CBATs) during the last five days in Monrovia and adjacent communities, about 35 communities have reported experiencing flooding over the last 72 hours. Data reported say that about 22,060 persons are caught up in the floods leading to temporary displacement, loss of valuable household items, and huge exposure to risks of disease outbreaks, loss of habitat (sheltering opportunities), livelihoods mechanisms, and water source pollution. About 60% of the affected people are women, children, and other vulnerable groups of people including physically challenged, single mothers, among others seeking shelter with neighbors and relatives in adjacent unflooded communities.

results.name: LBR: Flood - 06-2024 - Monrovia Floods

field_reports.description:
On Monday, March 26, at about 11:20 pm, a mining pit collapsed and killed 13 illicit miners, and unidentified numbers are still missing. The incident occurred in a community called Cheoh Town, some 21 kilometers away from Cestos City, the Capital city of River Cess County in south/central Liberia. The miners had gone there at night to conduct mining activities deep into the pit when the loose dirt collapsed, closing the way out of the hole. According to information from the County, this mining site had been closed by the government for some years, but illicit miners still go there at night in search of underground minerals, especially gold. 

After the situation occurred, some friends of the miners and community members carried out a search and rescue effort by digging off the top dirt to enter the pit to rescue some of their colleagues. Still, unfortunately, they retrieved only 13 dead bodies from the pit and three survivors. One of the survivors is currently undergoing treatment at JFK Hospital in Monrovia, and the other two who have broken legs are receiving traditional treatment in River Cess.

Meanwhile, the locals retired the search effort due to the lack of earth-moving equipment to more profound into the ground to dig out the remaining bodies and rescue anybody who was still alive.  On the other hand, The families/relatives of the 13 dead bodies have taken custody of their bodies for burial.
field_reports.summary: LBR: Other - 03-2024 - River Cess Gold Mine Mud Collapse

results.name: LBR: Other - 03-2024 - River Cess Gold Mine Mud Collapse

According to information from the County, this mining site had been closed by the government for some years, but illicit miners still go there at night in search of underground minerals, especially gold.

field_reports.description: On today, September 1, 2023, coastal floods and erosion swept through the Kru Town beach fishing community of Robersport City (capital of Grand Cape Mount County) in Western Liberia bordering Sierra Leone. The community of Kru Town has suffered sporadic incidents of erosion and flooding over the years. 1,955 persons are affected so far with 520 displaced in public buildings. The Liberian Red Cross has been coordinating with the National Disaster Management Agency (NDMA) on the response in the last 24 hours. The NS has deployed a surge support team from its HQ in Monrovia to the affected area to provide support to the volunteers and staff who are already conducting rapid assessments. NS is mobilizing local supplies from its warehouses to provide an initial response while engaging partners' support. The NDMA will support the response with coordination. Women and children are the most affected as photos show them displaced and sleeping in open buildings with no proper safety measures in place.

results.name: LBR: Flood - 2023-09 - Liberia: Robertsport Floods

field_reports.description: Two weeks of sporadic rainfall in Montserrado County (especially Monrovia) and Grand Cape Mount County respectively has led to flooding affecting 1,556 and displacing about 119 persons in Monrovia and adjacent communities in Grand Cape Mount County in the western part of the country at the border with Sierra Leone. Monrovia and its adjacent communities have a record of flooding in recent years. In the last 4 years, over 40,000 persons have been affected by flooding in most slum communities according to the National Disaster Management Agency. Since the last week of July, over 1,000 households have been affected by flood especially living in wetlands, swamps, and low flood plains in the slums of Monrovia and Robertsports (Capital of Grand Cape Mount County). Families are displaced in public and private facilities such as schools, health centers, churches, and mosques. In some instances in Monrovia, families are restrcited to leave their homes by high level rise of flood waters; they remain in their houses and are assisted with food and water by canoes reaching them by neighbors. Community roads and bridges are washed away preventing community people to have access to basic services. The poor conditions of community public utility facilities such as roads, bridges, etc also contribute to the risk and vulnerability of the affected population.

results.name: LBR: Flood - 2023-08 - Liberia Floods

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea and Guinea Bisau

results.name: LBR: September 2023 Floods
results.summary:
From 1st to 4th September, Liberia has experienced excessive heavy rainfall in several cities with highest flooding reported in North-Eastern counties of Liberia: Grand Cape Mount, Bong and Montserrado. Areas especially affected are Kru Town; Gbarnga City and Monrovia coastal and urban side as well as the surrounding areas. In total, around 15,200 people are reported to be affected by both urban and coastal floods which swept away infrastructure, fishing settlements, houses, communities' facilities etc. On 4th September, Monrovia and its environs recorded the major impact following the five days cumulative rains from 30 August that affected approximately 12,450 persons (1,778 HHs). The affected are mostly surrounding Moronvia or bordering Sierra Leone and the river crossing the North Est of the country.

The Liberia Meteorological Department has predicted continuous rains in September and October 2023 across all counties in the country. Obviously, with continuous heavy rainfall, it could trigger additional flooding in low-lying communities near rivers and streams. Urban flooding is also possible in areas with poor drainage systems. Sites downstream from large rivers are also vulnerable to flash flooding after relatively short periods of intense rainfall. These rains can cause further damage to infrastructure, road closures, and contamination.

field_reports.description: On Wednesday 1 March 2023, a heavy windstorm surge hit Gbarpolu and Grand Bassa Counties of Liberia, affecting more than thirteen communities. This natural disaster, which lasted for over an hour was responsible for tremendous infrastructural destruction, injury, and economic damages. Hundreds of people were severely injured including 58 children. At the moment no reported dead, but hundreds of people have been rendered homeless due to fallen trees and/or collapsed buildings. The Liberian National Red Cross has deployed staff and volunteers and are currently conducting a rapid assessment to ascertain the impact of the disaster and the needs of the affected population.
field_reports.summary: LBR: Storm Surge - 2023-03 - Gbarpolu and Grand Bassa Windstorm

results.name: LBR: Storm Surge - 2023-03 - Gbarpolu and Grand Bassa Windstorm
results.summary: On Sunday 12 February 2023, a heavy windstorm surge hit Gbarpolu and Grand Bassa Counties of Liberia, affecting fourteen villages. This natural disaster, which lasted for over an hour was responsible for tremendous infrastructural destruction, injuries, and economic damages. Hundreds of people were severely injured including 58 children. At moment, there are no reported deaths, but hundreds of people have been rendered homeless due to fallen trees and/or collapsed buildings. From available information, 1 village was affected in Gbarpolu County with 34 homes completely damaged and  27 homes partly destroyed affecting 434 people. In Grand Bassa County, 13 villages were affected affecting 41 homes, with a total of 278 people affected. The Liberian National Red Cross has deployed staff and volunteers who are currently conducting a rapid assessment to ascertain the impact of the disaster and the needs of the affected population.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: Case detected on 19th July 2022. Full investigation was conducted by the CSO and CDO and sample collection on 19th July 2022 and sent to National Reference Laboratory (NRL) for confirmation. The case tested positive for Monkeypox on July 25, 2022, by the National Reference Lab.
field_reports.description:
On 19th July 2022, a 43-year-old male patient (MD) presented at Pleebo Health Center with history of pustular rashes, on the face, head and other parts of the body, headache, muscle-ache, backache, and lymphadenopathy that started on 11th July 2022.  The case is a Liberian, who is reside and work in Ebokay Ville Une, Ivory Coast where he got infected. The case visited a health facility in Ivory Coast on July 14 where he did not receive any medications and decided to come back to Liberia to seek treatment.
According to the case finding report, he arrived in Liberia on 19th July 2022 and went to the Pleebo Health Center where he was pick-up in the triage and the health facility surveillance focal person was notified who immediately informed the DSO. Investigation was initiated by the DSO subsequently inform the CSO and CDO.
Full investigation was conducted by the CSO and CDO and sample collection on 19th July 2022 and sent to National Reference Laboratory (NRL) confirmation. The case tested positive for Monkeypox on July 25, 2022, by the National Reference Lab.  
The case is admitted at the Pleebo Health Center Isolation unit where he is being provided care treatment. Our investigation uncovered that the case has his family and resides in Pleebo city, Maryland County, but he moved with his wife and his one-year-old daughter to the Ivory Coast in search for a greener pasture. The case came directly to the health Center where he is currently isolated and undergoing treatment. He did not visit his family in Pleebo.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: Reports and data are provided by National Public Health Institute
field_reports.description:
The Ministry of Health in collaboration with the National Public Health Institute (NPHIL) have reported two cases of Monkey pox in the country and declared an outbreak of Monkey pox in the Country.
The Ministry of Health and National Public Health Institute along with partners are providing technical support to the County Health Teams.

Monkey pox is an illness caused by the monkey pox virus. It is a viral zoonotic infection, meaning that it can spread from animals to humans. It can also spread from person to person. Monkey pox can cause a range of signs and symptoms.  While some people have mild symptoms, others may develop more serious symptoms and need care in a health facility. Those at higher risk for severe disease or complications include people who are pregnant, children and persons that are immunocompromised.
The most common symptoms of monkey pox include FEVER, HEADACHE, MUSCLE ACHES, BACK PAIN, LOW ENERGY, and SWOLLEN LYMPH NODES. This is followed or accompanied by the development of a rash which can last for two to three weeks. The rash can be found on the face, palms of the hands, soles of the feet, eyes, mouth, throat, groin, and genital and/or anal regions of the body. The number of lesions can range from one to several thousand. Lesions begin flat, then fill with liquid before they crust over, dry up and fall off, with a fresh layer of skin forming underneath.
Symptoms of Monkey pox  include:
•	Fever
•	Headache
•	Muscle aches and backache
•	Swollen lymph nodes
•	Chills
•	Exhaustion
•	A rash that can look like pimples or blisters that appears on the face, inside the mouth, and on other parts of the body, like the hands, feet, chest, genitals, or anus.
The rash goes through different stages before healing completely. The illness typically lasts 2-4 weeks. Sometimes, people get a rash first, followed by other symptoms. Others only experience a rash.
field_reports.summary: LBR: Epidemic - 2022-07 - Monkey Pox Outbreak in Liberia

results.name: LBR: Epidemic - 2022-07 - Monkey Pox Outbreak in Liberia

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea and Guinea Bisau

field_reports.description: Liberia has experienced ceaseless rainfall since 4th July 2022 leading to heavy flooding in three counties (Montserrado-Monrovia, Margibi, and Cape Mount). The National Disaster Management Agency (NDMA) has reported a total of 90,640 (17,000 households) are affected across these counties as a result of the floods. A total of 55 communities in these counties are reported affected; 46 of those communities are in Montserrado County.  Three (3) deaths (children) have been reported and 1 is confirmed. The government of Liberia through the NDMA has declared the situation an emergency.  Livelihoods are interrupted; water sources are contaminated posing a high risk of water and vector-borne disease outbreaks. Basic household items are damaged and several families are displaced.

contacts.name: John Gbao
contacts.title: Senior Operations Officer, Country Cluster Delegation for Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and Guinea Bissau

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: The reported data reflects three (3) counties, namely Nimba, Bassa, and Montserrado. Children under 5 are mostly being affected according to the reports. The situation is evolving as we gather data from other counties; the Government, through the Chief Medical Officer of Liberia reported that there is an outbreak of measles in 14 of the 15 counties with unconfirmed deaths; The NS is monitoring and following up with the MoH.
field_reports.description:
Liberia’s Health Ministry has confirmed an outbreak of measles, affecting 14 of the 15 counties in the country. Chief Medical Officer, Dr. Francis Kateh, said there were reports of deaths in the wake of the outbreak, but he was not sure if they were all measles-related. He told a radio program on Wednesday, 20th April that the outbreak was a result of low immunization rates, especially during the Covid-19 outbreak and duration. Parents have held back from availing their children of immunization due to vaccine resistance to COVID-19. 
According to the National Public Health Institute’s weekly update on the Liberia Public Health Surveillance & Response System (Reporting Week 14; Reporting Period: April 4-10) on measles, 204 suspected cases including 3 deaths were reported. Montserrado County accounts for 66% (135 cases) of the total cases reported. 
The Government has reported major capacity challenges to adequately address the response. They are identifying community cases and making referrals to health facilities in the counties. The Ministry has also confirmed a planned circumscribed vaccination campaign shortly. 
Breakdown of cases per county includes Montserrado County (135), Nimba (21), Grand Bassa (17), Lofa (12), Margibi (8), Grand Gedeh (3), Sinoe (2), Grand Cape Mount (2), River Gee (1), Maryland (1), Grand Kru (1), and Bomi (1).

According to the MoH, children are mostly affected by the outbreak.
field_reports.summary: LBR: Epidemic - 2022-04 - Measles Outbreak in Liberia

results.name: LBR: Epidemic - 2022-04 - Measles Outbreak in Liberia

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: All cases are from one health district (Sanniquellie Mah); communities – Glehnlu, LPMC. Success, Guinea Road, and Gbarpa.
field_reports.description:
Lassa Fever outbreak reported in Sanniquellie Mah, Liberia with six confirmed cases, of which four already dead and two presently in isolation. All cases are from one health district (Sanniquellie Mah); communities – Glehnlu, LPMC. Success, Guinea Road, and Gbarpa. Other three new cases have been suspected involving 1 female and two males and are currently in isolation with required medical attention. At the moment, there is no further spread beyond the index health district. Investigation of the cases by the District Health Team with support from the County Health Team and WHO has been ongoing. A total of 79 contacts have been line-listed to-date of which 47 are health workers. The outbreak is still at the level of the District and County health Teams’ control. The MoH at the national level continues to provide remote technical support while the NCHT carries on the response along with the district officers. 

The NCHT have expressed challenge of body bags as a major constraint in this type of infectious respond. Therefore, the CHT is asking the LNRCS to support with body bags. IMS meetings are ongoing at the moment in Nimba County every Wednesday; hence the Surveillance Team meets daily after their regular field visits.
